item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

I admit I was wrong with my predictions about FOOS and governments in my last post.

However I still think FOOS goes against free market principles because they rely on having incentives to do stuff.

If your company makes bad software, you’ll go out of business and end up starving to death, thus everybody will try to make good software.
FOOS people volunteer their spare time to contribute to a FOOS project with no promise of monetary return. If they make bad software that nobody uses… nothing happens. They have no incentive to make their software better.

So free market principles predict that paid-for software will always be better than FOOS.

I reckoned neo-liberal governments wouldn’t want to use FOOS because that would mean admitting the market isn’t always perfect. But since they have, I think that means these governments are not as right-wing as I thought they would be.

item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:19, topic:364693”][quote author=yakman link=topic=460897.msg3386709#msg3386709 date=1288525275]
It will take a long time, if ever, before governments like the British or US switch.
[/quote]

Our government already drew up cost-benefit analysis for switching to open source, and got praise from people in the open source world for it being more realistic/a bigger step than many other governments have taken (this was a few years ago, though).

They said they would switch when it became more cost-effective, which they foresaw happening soon.[/quote]
I believe that for 99% of their work, open source variations of Microsoft software would suffice. MS Word, as an example, is extremely bloated with bells and whistles these days – that’s what they compete with now.
Anyone happy with using a word processor as a word processor, rather than wanting to produce extremely fancy documents, can make do with Open Office.

Having said that, vendor lock in is a big problem in the academic realm. I find that documents I make in Open Office don’t come out as I expect when they’re opened in MS Word. I choose to do things like essays on the university computers for that reason.

I imagine that MS Excel would have some useful features that the Open Office version doesn’t, but I don’t use it so I could be wrong.

item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Elijah:

I think the reason they’re afraid of open source is even though an up-to-date Linux system is VERY secure, a Legacy install, that hasn’t had patches is very vulnerable. And considering most government establishments are painfully slow when it comes to updating their software, it’s obviously a bit risky to run something that’s open source, and all the documentation is there to find holes in their security.

They could skip right past Linux and use OpenBSD where appropriate if their primary concern is security – OpenBSD has a full disclosure policy when it comes to security flaws, excellent documentation (probably not as good as FreeBSD’s though), and it’s configured properly right out of the box. If the box remains properly configured after extra services are enabled (ie, everything runs with minimum permissions and so on) then I really doubt someone would get in remotely using anything less than a brute force attack.
Apparently they’ve had only 2 security issues with the default installation in the last decade.

Anyway, the best thing about OpenBSD is that every aspect of the primary software is under BSD code; it doesn’t ship with GPL’d code by default iirc, unlike FreeBSD. So it’s ‘free’ as in freedom, not ‘free’ as in ‘free, but…’ – the governments using such software could make in-house changes appropriate to the environment they’re using it in without being compelled to share those changes. I imagine a government would value this.

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:5, topic:364693”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=460897.msg3373058#msg3373058 date=1287370627]

Awesome, hopefully all governments will go this way soon.

http://www.guardian.co.uk/technology/blog/2010/feb/23/opensource-intellectual-property
[/quote]

That’s the most ridiculous thing I’ve ever seen. Plus I know for a fact that the US government, armed forces, and defense contractors heavily use open source software as well. (every job posting for these types of jobs that I see requires Linux experience, and my grandfather-in-law who works in IT for the air force told me they use Linux a lot as well)[/quote]
You’re telling me. I first read about it months ago, and obviously still haven’t forgotten. It’d quite possibly be the biggest and best piss take of the decade IF it was a joke. Unfortunately it isn’t.
